column4: ctrl+alt+f1 should give you a text console to log in. then check with ls -la if all the files in your home folder belong to you and not to root.
ill check, brb
yeah some are root, by the way how do us scrol up in terminal?
shift+pageup
maybe one of these files are the problem. you should probably chown them back to your user
yea, don't see why any of them should be root either, so how would I do that?
chown $USER.$USER file(s)
you probably used sudo for a gui application that wrote these. that is what gksudo would solve
ah ok gksudo prevents root files in home?
well ill use chown on files brb
well it didn't work, I might have done something with the sessions
next step would eb moving the .gnome and such folder away. this would make the applications start up with the defaults again (w/o the need to create a new user)
or use mv for move
k hope it works
didn't work, noticed that it didn'
hm maybe one of the other folder. you could use adduser and create a new account. so you'd at least know if the system works basically
yeah got to check that, this looks a little messed, brb, adduser right?
are you booting into an other system each time? because you could do this without rebooting. but you'd need to use a text mode chat then ;-)
irssi. not using it myself but you'll find a fan club in this channel :-)
looking it up, ill have it install, this was getting depressing, booting into windows and all lol
ok tried the new user, it dind't work, system is screwd up :(
